note.p: James Phelan served in the Confederate Senate from Mississippi.

Born on October 11, 1821, in Huntsville, Alabama, Phelan gained experience in newspaper editing during his teenage years, working for the Democrat and the Flag of the Union. In 1843, he was appointed the Alabama state printer. Soon after he turned his attention to legal practice and became an attorney in 1846. Phelan moved to Aberdeen, Mississippi, in 1849 and started a successful law firm.

In 1860, Phelan won a seat in the Mississippi State Senate and served in that role until he was elected as one of Mississippi’s first senators to the First Confederate Congress. He served from 1862 to 1864. His most notable act as a Confederate senator was the introduction of legislation authorizing the government to confiscate cotton from southern citizens, with Confederate bonds given in exchange, for foreign loans. The bill generated a great deal of anger across the south and was defeated in the Senate. Phelan lost reelection in 1864.

After the Civil War, Phelan moved to Memphis, Tennessee and practiced law. He died on May 17, 1873, at the age of 52. Phelan was married to Elizabeth Jones Moore and had five children. He is buried in Odd Fellows Rest Cemetery in Aberdeen, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave)

James H. Rives was a Confederate soldier and the Mississippi governor’s private secretary during the Civil War.

Born in 1830 in Georgia, Rives moved to Noxubee County, Mississippi, as a young man and became a practicing attorney. When the Civil War broke out in 1861, Rives volunteered for military service, and was commissioned as an officer in a militia company named the Noxubee Rifles. He received a commission in the Confederate army when the company was incorporated into the Eleventh Mississippi Infantry Regiment as Company F.

By late 1862, Rives had left the regiment and accepted an appointment as private secretary to Mississippi governor John J. Pettus. He served in that role for most of 1863. After the war, Rives returned to Noxubee County and practiced law. He married Leona Cotton in 1868 and had at least one daughter. Rives was active in Noxubee County politics in the late 1860s and early 1870s, and was called before the U.S. Congress to testify to about race relations in Mississippi in 1871. He died in 1875.

(Vicksburg Whig, Vicksburg, MS, February 13, 1861; Ancestry.com, Mississippi, U.S., Compiled Marriage Index, 1776-1935; “Copy of a letter from Mississippi Governor John J. Pettus; December 1, 1862,” Civil War and Reconstruction Governors of Mississippi, mdah_757-943-04-02; Wikipedia; Record of Wills [Noxubee County, Mississippi], 1834-1926; Testimony Taken By The Joint Select Committee To Inquire Into The Condition Of Affairs In The Late Insurrectionary States, 548)

note.p: John Jones Pettus was Mississippi's governor during the first three years of the Civil War.

Born in Wilson County, Tennessee, on October 9, 1813, Pettus moved to Limestone County, Alabama, as a child. In 1835, he moved to Mississippi and eventually began a law practice in Scooba, Mississippi. He married Permelia Winston in the 1840s. She passed away in 1857, and in 1861 Pettus married Susan Hewell.

Pettus began pursuing a political career in the mid-1840s, first serving as a state representative for Kemper County. He won a state Senate election in 1848 and by 1853 had risen to president of the Mississippi Senate. Then, in January 1854, Governor Henry S. Foote resigned in protest before Governor-elect John J. McRae was inaugurated. Pettus’ position in the Senate placed him next in line to fill the governor’s vacancy, and he was sworn in as Mississippi’s interim executive on January 7, 1854. He served in that role for only three days, before McRae was inaugurated on January 10.

Pettus won the governor’s election in 1859. By that time, he had become a notable secessionist. He advocated for the creation of an independent Confederacy dedicated to preserving slavery. When Abraham Lincoln was elected president in 1860, Pettus called forth a special legislative session in Mississippi and pressed state representatives to hold a secession convention. His efforts succeeded, as such convention assembled in January 1861 and voted in support of secession, declaring the State of Mississippi out of the Union. Pettus won reelection for governor in 1861 and served until his term ended in 1863. Mississippi’s Constitution had a two-term limit for the governor’s office, leaving Pettus unable to run again. He took a commission as a colonel in the Mississippi State Troops and served until the end of the war. Shortly thereafter, Pettus moved to Arkansas. He applied for a presidential pardon according to President Andrew Johnson’s Reconstruction policies, but was denied three times.
Pettus died of pneumonia on January 25, 1867. He is buried in Flat Bayou Cemetery, Jefferson County, Arkansas.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave)

gloss.p: Established in 1861, Stuart, Buchanan and Company controlled the salt works in Saltville, Virginia, the Confederacy’s most important and highest yielding supply of salt. The company was owned by William Stuart, Ben K. Buchanan, George Palmer, and Joseph Jacques. Stuart was an older brother of notable Confederate cavalry officer JEB Stuart. Palmer had arrived in Saltville in the late 1850s with experience in salt production at Onondaga in New York and restructured the Saltville production facilities to model the effective Syracuse method of extracting salt from brine water, drawn from underground. The process involved boiling the water in kettles over a long furnace.

Salt was a vital commodity for food preservation and other domestic and industrial purposes in the nineteenth century. Therefore, when the Civil War began, Confederate and southern state officials quickly sought reliable sources of the mineral. Stuart, Buchanan and Company signed a contract to provide 22,000 bushels (slightly over one million pounds) of salt per month for the Confederate military. The company expanded its production from one furnace and around 70 kettles to 38 furnaces and more than 2,500 kettles. The facilities were so successful that Stuart, Buchanan and Company produced enough salt to meet the Confederate contract and have enough to sell to other southern states, such as Alabama and North Carolina. The local railroad could not sufficiently transport the amount of salt produced at Saltville, leading to wagon trains arriving to cart the mineral to consumers. Union soldiers briefly captured Saltville in December 1864 and destroyed many of the salt production furnaces and equipment. The company partially rebuilt and was back in production by March 1865, but the end of the war followed shortly afterwards. (Robert C. Whisonant, Arming the Confederacy: How Virginia’s Minerals Forged the Rebel War Machine, 100–101; “Civil War Minerals,” Virginia Department of Energy)

div.p:
Hon A. T. Caperton
Richmond Va.
The communication of James H. Rives private secretary to Gov: Pettus of Mississippi, handed to me by you this morning requires some notice at my hand though not addressed to me—

I am perfectly familiar with what occurred between our firm and the agent sent by Gov Pettus to our works last fall. I allude to the saltworks of Stuart Buchanan Hes at Saltville Va.— [gap] We did not believe then that the wells we were operating would yield salt water enough to supply our obligations then existing—and leave any sur=plus for Miss—An Agent from the State of South Carolina was present at the works at the time of the visit of Gov Pettus' Agent & was negotiating for the privilege of salt water for his state— [gap] We (Stuart Buchan-an &Co) offered to let those agents sink a well for their joint use—or each sink a well for his own state—and then give them all privileges given to other states making salt at Saltsville, they paying us seventy five cents per bushel on the salt they might make

which was the price agreed to be paid us by the States of North Carolina, Tennessee, & Alabama—I think we were also willing to allow a credit for digging the well, against the charge for salt water—but of this I am not positive—

As to the other allegation that we are demand-ing of agents & Salt buyers from Miss two 25/100 dollars for salt water sufficient to make a bushel of salt, I am not well informed of the facts on which it rests—Mr. Palmer (one of our firm) informed me that he had had a negotiation with a gentleman from Miss during my absence, and that he was to receive about the price stated for Salt water—but he added that we were to give up to this gentleman our interest of 3/4ths in a furnace in operation—& I think had to guarantee ^salt^ water—We pump salt water for other states, but guarantee nothing The other states put up their works early last summer before the advance in prices of salt & other articles

As to making any distinction between states, or between individuals from different States—applying for privileges at the same time & of the same character, we are inno=cent I am sure—For instance Virginia
If I find on my return home, the facts different from those stated, I will write you—

Hon James Phelan
M. C.
Richmond Va
